direction.raw_text: Now comes the moon riding over the horizon. Upon a hill at the edge of the wood squats a castle, its crude stonework bathed in cold silvery light. Queer carvings and runes decorate the ponderous gate. Heavy vines are climbing up the walls. The castle is old, its unfamiliar form testament to an ancient mind and an ancient craft. Flickering candle light dances on a leaded windowpane. Inside, the corridors are dark and silent. Under low arched ceilings the uneven floors are paved with stone blocks. Perched over lintels and crouched in niches are icons with strange animal heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sleep on a straw palette in a room strewn with vegetables and crockery is Hodge, a wrinkled old retainer. A flickering candle and empty jug are beside the bed. He is snoring gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This circular chamber at the heart of the castle is stuffed with parchments, scrolls, dusty books, bronze braziers, glass retorts, chemical salts, birds both stuffed and caged. An iron candelabra stands on a work table, tapers burning. In the soft glow it seems that the room is unoccupied, but no, moving in the background is a shadowy figure, preparing for a magical deed. Feet are positioned carefully within a pentagram chiseled into the floor. A scroll is consulted; up comes an arm and a voice blurts out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing happens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the little flames stand at attention without so much as a tremble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's no use. There is a sigh and the figure moves forward into the light. Revealed in the glow is the discouraged face of Galen Bradwardyn, sorcerer's apprentice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Omnia in duos: Duo in Unum: Unus in Nihil: Haec nec Quattuor nec Omnia nec Duo nec Unus nec Nihil Sunt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, candles, out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In Volunta Divina et Verbum Magi: Lux! Exstinguat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carrying the candelabra, the youth trudges up a circular staircase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The highest point of the castle is a turret, open to the stars and the night air. Here, more magic is afoot. An old enchanter, Ulrich, Magister Ipsissimus, pours water from a silver ewer into a stone bowl. As the surface ripples disappear he leans forward and gazes into the pool. All at once his face hardens as the distant sounds of screams and thunder reach his ears. Lights and shadows, reflected from within the basin, play across his face. His frown deepens as the sound of his own voice comes to him from the vision in the water -- Draco draconis -- suddenly squelched by the roar of flame and an ugly snarl. At that moment Galen reaches the top of the steps and holds up the candelabra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ulrich, startled from his trance, slaps the water out of the basin and turns to confront his student. Galen is taken aback by the old man's grim countenance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a distracted gesture he causes the flames to extinguish themselves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Vide, Magister. There's something wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? What's happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've just seen something. Something of consequence to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calm) Yes. My own death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps we had better hasten your training.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Outside the castle wall Hodge is feeding the chickens and ducks. He straightens up and squints through the early morning mists. On a distant hillock two figures are moving toward the woods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hobbling slowly with the aid of a pair of canes, Ulrich guides his pupil across a wooden bridge and along a stream into the forest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ulrich gauges the young man standing before him and makes a decision. Reaching under his cloak he lifts off a fine silver chain with an amulet dangling from it. He drapes it around Galen's neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen instinctively wraps his hand around the jewel. He cocks an ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hastens forward to a promontory, eager to have a look. Ulrich does not follow. Instead, doffing his cloak, he whirls it before him, where it magically floats a few feet off the ground. Awkwardly, the old man clambers aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back, but the wizard is gone. A shadow falls over him. He looks up. There, two hundred feet above the tree tops his master is soaring on the wind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (stern and troubled) This wood, these leaves, the birds, the very dome of heaven, once they all rang with one great chord: and philosophers like me kept it all in tune. Now, new voices are singing new songs. (sharply) Have you mastered the threefold transmutation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (skeptical) You have?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, almost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's very difficult. Have you committed to memory undying the Codex de Profundis?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a shrug) The first two chapters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's long. And what about the Ritual of Banishment as prescribed by my late master Balisarius?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To tell the truth, I haven't dared try it. What's the point, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The point? The point is you don't know it, and you're no magician without it. It was my hope to school you, to mold your faculties and wits... I still believe you have some talent. Somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hate books. I hate drill. I want a real task.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no time now. When I'm gone, half the powers in the universe will vanish with me. And what's the use of a few lingering skills if they're left in the hands of a child? (pause) Listen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't hear anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, wear this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Voices, singing on the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The old conjurer squints into the distance. Miles away and far below a company of drab walkers winds along the margins of the forest. They are singing a mournful round.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gawks skyward. Suddenly, the old man leans down and addresses him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a shout) We have visitors!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clustering together in the center of a wide reception hall is a contingent of weary peasants, awkward amidst the dusty rugs, drapes and heavy furniture. Their leader is a fineboned youth, not yet twenty. Like the others, he is uneasy; his name is Valerian. Hodge enters and sets a tray of mead before them. He leaves without a word. The visitors stare glumly at the refreshment, but are too timorous to go near it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen helps Ulrich prepare for the audience. The sorcerer peers at himself in a full-length mirror, adjusting the hem of a black robe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He backs away from the mirror and fits a silver coronet onto his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sorcerer starts down a circular stone staircase.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Looks forbidding enough, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here are your sticks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- they'll think me infirm. You know, Balisarius wore this whenever he changed lead into gold. He could really do that, you know. I never could. Too bad -- you'd stand to inherit some real wealth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're in a morbid frame of mind. What's all this about dying? You don't even look sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tying on a sash) You still wearing that amulet? (Galen nods) Good. Don't lose it. It still belongs to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, adeptus minor, get yourself a handful of that sulphurous ash over there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The visitors watch warily as a door swings open and Galen makes his entrance, his face expressionless and hands pressed together. He looks rather young to be the famous Ulrich. Galen allows a moment to go by, then throws his arms wide. Ka-whump! and Ulrich appears in the doorway in a smoky fireball. Alarmed, the visitors retreat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pffst! around the room candles flare in their niches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the fireplace, the birch logs are suddenly ablaze. Ulrich totters to the hearth and extends long bony fingers toward the warmth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The travelers are suitably dazzled by the magician's performance. The young leader of the party screws up his courage and speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The travelers exchange nervous glances. Valerian motions to one of his companions. The man steps forward and hands over a leather pouch. One by one, Valerian places the contents on the table for Ulrich's inspection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this, Ulrich advances and closely examines three shimmering irridescent disks as big as saucers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valerian reaches under his jerkin and withdraws what appears to be a curved sword. He jabs it into the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs a finger along a serrated edge and gazes bleakly at his visitors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valerian has lost all trace of timidity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a sigh, Ulrich lowers himself into a chair. He rubs his withered legs and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greil, a grizzled peasant, speaks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen edges over to the table and inspects the scales and tooth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He broods for a long time.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nunc habeus lux!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Et calor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome to Cragganmore. I am Ulrich. Which one of you calls himself Valerian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be me. We are here on behalf...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know why you're here. You're a delegation from Urland, from beyond Dalvatia. Let's see the artifacts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A bone. Scorched. A rock, fire- blackened. (pause) Scales.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. How did you come by these?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly) I found them. At the mouth of the lair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grim) What else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A claw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's no claw. It's a tooth. By the gods!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you want me to do battle with that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who else can we turn to? We all know what we're dealing with here. This is a basilicok. (he takes a step forward) A cockatrice. (another step, bolder) A dragon. (he leans close to Ulrich) This is no stag, no bear, no natural creature. This is one of your kind. And only a necromancer such as yourself can rid us of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you try the Meredydd sisters? What about Rinbod? I've heard it said he killed a dragon once.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're all dead. You're the only one left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a long way to Urland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every quarter, upon the solstices and the equinoxes there's a new victim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daughter, for one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My sister... cousins...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All women?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Girls. Virgins, to be exact, chosen by lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Master, don't you think -- ULRICH Silence!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you afraid of dragons?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Sorcerers and dragons go back a long long time together. If it weren't for sorcerers, there wouldn't be any dragons. (pause) All right. I'll go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The travelers are making ready for departure in the grey light of dawn. As Hodge stuffs provisions into a wicker box, Ulrich wraps padding on a newly fashioned pair of crutches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hodge mutters something inaudible and grimly keeps packing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen crouches against the castle wall; he regards his master sullenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen gets up and calls out to the Urlanders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is too much for Hodge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen approaches the old sorcerer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The walkers are ready to set forth. Hodge picks up his pack, steps forward and pulls open the great gate.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know of this dragon. Vermithrax Pejorative: she's four hundred years old. As far as I can tell she's the last of her kind. Very appropriate that I'm the one to finish her off, don't you think? (he tries out the crutches) There. Flatten the highest mountain. What say you, Galen? (no answer) Speak up. (still no answer) You, Hodge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Galen) While I'm gone see you keep your nose in your books and your hands out of my reagents. Leave my instruments alone too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at yourself. How far will you get like that? A league, two leagues?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not worried about the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) Why don't you wave your hands around and summon up a coach-and-four?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't mock me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You pilgrims: You're used to lotteries. Why not draw straws to see who'll be first to carry ironshanks here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold your tongue. If the master's got a mind to go, he'll go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Send me. You're always saying I need seasoning. I need a test. Let me go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm ready for anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wan smile) Don't be so hasty. Your time will come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Three mounted men are outside the gate, helmets on their heads, swords on the belts and longbows across their shoulders. They look formidable. The Urlanders take a step backward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian is a lean, heavily bearded nobleman. There is a coat of arms on the shield strapped to the pommel of his saddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sensing trouble, Galen moves forward. Ulrich touches his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen hears the urgency in the old man's voice and obeys. Hodge takes it upon himself to deal with the strangers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian dismounts and saunters up to the old magician.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When Ulrich finally speaks, his voice is low and authoritative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen's eyes widen with alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen dashes into the castle. Ulrich gazes almost shyly at Tyrian.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tyrian!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amiable) Good morning, all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not afraid of you. Give us the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, the road is yours. All the way to Urland. It's a long journey, isn't it? But when you're in search of a sorcerer, I suppose no distance is too great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under his breath) Say nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, like my good friends here, I've come for a bit of black magic. No doubt you've heard of our troubles at home. This is Cragganmore, is it not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aye, this be the place of Ulrich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here we have the mystical presence himself, no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd best keep your distance -- and your manners.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he's ready to lay a dragon in its grave, he's got nothing to fear from me. (turns to the Urlanders) I've no more love for that creature than you lot. Nor has the King. But, before you stir things up, don't you think it a good idea to see you've got the right man for the job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aha -- it's a test you're looking for. We don't do tests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure you don't. They never do tests -- and not many real deeds either. Oh, conversation with your grandmother's shade in a darkened room, the odd love potion or two... but comes a doubter, well then, it's the wrong day, the planets are not aligned, the entrails aren't favorable, we don't do tests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got no doubts. We require no test.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're not going to get one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Galen) Go to the conjuring room. The iron box. Fetch me the dagger within.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The dagger. Be quick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shall have your test.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen comes puffing up the steps, locates the iron box, and flings it open. Amidst the tawdry paraphernalia of a professional magician is an ivory-handled dagger covered with runic inscriptions. Galen eagerly examines it to see how the blade might twist aside or collapse into the handle, but it is all too genuine. A murder weapon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen throws open a window and looks down into the courtyard. He displays the dagger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen hesitates, then tosses it. Tumbling end over end, it arcs downward. The old conjurer calmly stretches out a hand and plucks it neatly out of the air. Galen watches as Ulrich passes the weapon to Tyrian and strips back his robe exposing a bony chest. Galen knows what's coming. He rushes for the door. He's only a step away when it bangs shut of its own accord. He sprints for a second exit. Whack! This door slams shut too. Locked in. Quick, back to the window and climb down the vine... Smack! the heavy shutters seal him in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (impatient) Where are you, boy? I'm waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not this one, was it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The very one. Let it fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ulrich takes Tyrian's arm and guides the point of the dagger to his breastbone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is filled with dread. Hodge is shaking. From the castle come the rattling of shutters and Galen's muffled cries. A sick sarcastic smile has crept over Tyrian's lips. He tenses himself to thrust.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Vita regula, vita hieratica!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on. Don't worry, you can't hurt me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen stops hammering and presses his face to a crack in the shutter. Below he can see the participants in this grisly drama. He holds his breath. Tyrian makes a sudden movement and buries the blade in Ulrich's chest. But the sorcerer stands unbent, seemingly unhurt. Then, after a long moment, he slowly sags forward over the dagger and the hand that holds it. Tyrian shrinks back and allows the body to fall in a heap. Very quickly he remounts. In another moment he and his companions are gone. The others are riveted in horror. Hodge sinks to his knees and wails his grief. Galen turns away from the window and gazes blankly into the gloomy conjuring room. Click! The doors unlatch themselves and swing open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ulrich, principal magician and sorcerer of the western world, reposes on a hardwood pyre. His hands are folded on his chest. His face is peaceful. While the visitors wordlessly look on, Galen touches a burning brand to the kindling. At first the fire catches normally enough, but when the flames start to envelop the body they suddenly turn pale green, producing an unearthly roar. The onlookers back away from the intense heat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The erstwhile apprentice stands his ground, blinking back tears, his face weirdly illuminated by the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen sits alone amidst the museum-like collection of magical apparatus. He stares at the amulet, considering its significance. His reverie is interrupted by the murmur of voices below. At the window he looks down to see Hodge bidding farewell to the delegation from Urland. Valerian is the last to leave. He pauses at the gate and glances up at Galen. Then he moves on. The young student of magic sets his jaw, suddenly filled with resolve. Moving through the room, he busies himself with the old man's effects. He scoops up the loose books and parchments and locks them into trunks. He drapes muslin cloths over the alchemical devices. He sows a handful of salt over the pentagram inscribed in the floor. Finally, he opens the cages and releases the crow, the falcon, and the great horned owl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hodge is up on the burned out funeral pyre, anxiously scraping ashes and small bones into a leather pouch -- the remains of Ulrich. Up behind him comes Galen, now clad in a traveler's cloak, with a pack on his back and a staff in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hodge quickly conceals the pouch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He quickly climbs down, picks up his pack and follows Galen out through the gate. As the door is pushed shut a huge oaken timber falls into place, barring the castle against the uninvited.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hodge -- what are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just making my farewell, thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen and Hodge labor to the crest of a grassy hill and turn to look back across a wide valley. There on another hilltop on the far side sits Cragganmore, lit by the red rays of the setting sun. Galen removes the amulet from his neck and clutches it in his fist. Hodge is bug-eyed to see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his hands toward the castle and calls out:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Be careful with that! You don't know what you're doing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cragganmore! Domus non i am! Silva celet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The vines on the castle walls begin to twitch and stretch, magically brought to animate life. They flow upward over the masonry, branching out and covering every surface, then up onto the roof. Finally only the tops of the chimneys and the highest turrets stand above the green carpet. A century's growth in a matter of seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & HODGE On their hilltop the old retainer gives the youth a fearful look. Galen is too flushed with excitement over what he has done to notice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen and Hodge trudge along an overgrown cart-track under an arch of trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The apprentice's mind is elsewhere: he's got a coin hovering in mid-air above his palm, bobbing gently as he walks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plucks a low-hanging leaf, waves a hand over it, and watches it turn into a spray of daffodils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives the pack a slap. It flies out of its harness and floats alongside them. Hodge snatches it back and clutches it tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A great coat drapes itself over Hodge's shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The greatcoat disappears, as do the rest of his garments, leaving him in his smalls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suppressing a grin, Galen mercifully waves his hand and restores Hodge to his usual costume.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it's a vale of tears in which we dwell. It doesn't matter who you are, a king in his robes, a peasant in his rags, when your time comes, no magic can save you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...the kindest lord a man could ask for... now he's gone. Ye gods he was fussy about his bath. And you'd think he could boil his own eggs with the snap of a finger, but no, he had old Hodge do it, of course. (snurfling) Up before five I was, mucking out the cages, slopping the pigs, and never once got so much as a thankyou or a pat on the back... (through tears) I'm going to miss him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me too...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No you don't. All you care about is the tricks and knavery. Well, you don't pull any wool over these old eyes. It'll be a mighty long walk before you fill his shoes, you mark my word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, Hodge, pack too heavy? Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Careful with that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too cold, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too warm?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (spluttering) Stop it, I say! Out of respect for the master!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got as much respect for the master as anyone, old man. But -- then again, I'm master now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Urlanders are gathered around a fire, sharing a meager supper. The man named Greil pokes at the stew-pot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks up and down behind Valerian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkin, an older man, speaks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a noise from the darkness beyond the campfire. Two of the men get to their feet and listen. At first silence, then more rustling. Without a word the two men dart into the bushes and haul two interlopers before the company: Galen and Hodge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen surveys the puzzled faces. He draws himself up and plunges in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a moment of depressed silence. Hodge rolls his eyes. Greil starts to chuckle, then to laugh. Soon the others are laughing too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone brings out a dagger and hands it to Greil. Valerian pushes it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Greil persists, waving the knife at the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lashes out with the knife. Galen jumps back, but Valerian steps in, delivering a quick kick to Greil's gut, followed by a right to the jaw that sends the bigger man sprawling. He takes the knife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He propels Galen out of harm's way and sits him down on the other side of the fire. Greil nurses his jaw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valerian hands Galen a plate of food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both look up at the moon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I left my farm with seeds unplanted, calves unborn, nothing but a wife to chase down the strays, and for what? A funeral, that's what.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because some people said, find a magician. Not just a local fellow, an import, a good forty leagues from home. An all-powerful necromancer. Ha -- some necromancer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold your tongue, Greil. Sit. Eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll not sit. I'll not eat. See you the Great Bear. His tail points east. It's the equinox. Have you forgotten? Or rather not think about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (miserable) He's right. I brought us here for nothing. May the gods help whoever's daughter it is tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morrow, good morrow. Peace be with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy now. We mean no harm. We've been looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (growl) Well, you've found us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (brushing himself off) More the other way around, I'd say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A few words, that's all. You were looking for a conjurer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Requiscat in pace. (he takes a deep breath) Ecce: magister novus!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How say you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My lord Ulrich is no longer. All that you asked of him, you may now expect of me. The dangers he would face, I will now conquer. The task he would undertake I will now fulfill. I am Galen Bradwardyn, inheritor of Ulrich's craft and knowledge, and I am the Sorcerer you seek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's a handsome thought, O wizard of wizards. But if there's one thing our friend Tyrian has shown us, it's to beware the pig in the poke. Who's got a dagger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No tests!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call it proof, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've seen enough tests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I haven't. All I've seen is death. Death in our families, death on the road, and tonight, death at home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's come over you, anyway? Have you lost your wits?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like it. Young snot-nose comes in here for sport at our expense. We're on a fool's errand, but we don't have to listen to this. I don't want to hear any more about sorcery. I don't want to hear any more about spells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be hungry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) What's the matter with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not just him. It's all of us. It's the equinox.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The moon shines down on the far reaches of the Kingdom of Urland, coldly lighting a barren landscape filled with the skeletons of dead trees, blackened rock and bare ground. Advancing across this mournful terrain is a troop of armed men leading a blindfolded horse and tumbril. The horse is skittish. Finally, in spite of shouts and lashings, it refuses to go further. The leader, Horsrik, barks out an order:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young woman, no more than seventeen, is brought forth from the cart. Long black hair falls down over a white tunic. Her dark eyes dart fearfully around in her pale face. She is half-carried, half dragged to the edge of a steaming crack in the ground where she is manacled to a wooden post. By lantern-light, Horsrik reads from a parchment scroll.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a low rumble; the earth shakes. Horsrik glances nervously around. He carries on by rote.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He prods the girl, but she is too terrified to speak. Beneath them, the earth seems to groan. Smoke issues from the mouth of the pit. One of the nervous witnesses leans forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The horse suddenly rears, and blindfold notwithstanding, gallops off, dragging the tumbril over the rocks. The men behind Horsrik break ranks and scatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Horsrik joins the flight, chasing his men back over the murky horizon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Close enough! Bring her out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now be it known throughout the kingdom, that this maiden, having lawfully been chosen by a deed of fortune and destiny, shall hereby give up her life for the greater good of Urland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By this act shall be satisfied the powers that dwell underground and the spirits that attend thereto. In gratitude for this sacrifice His Majesty has declared the family -- what's the name? --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plowman! The family Plowman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rushing it)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: the family Plowman to be free of obligations, taxations, levys and imposts for a period not to exceed five years...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ordained and signed this day, etc., Casiodorus, in his glory the reigning king of this our realm... his seal, his mark, duly read by Chancellor Horsrik in his holy name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She strains against her manacles, cocking her head to listen as the rumblings below subside. Presently the steam and smoke blow away and she can see the horse pawing and stamping a hundred yards distant, the wheel of the cart jammed between rocks. Summoning up a wild will to live, she squeezes her hands against the cold iron rings. No use. She spits on her wrists and twists desperately. Blood starts. One hand slips free. She looks at the horse. The animal tosses off its blindfold and looks back at her. Now she strains again and pulls her other hand free. She wipes the blood on her frock and sprints toward the horse. But she doesn't get there. The earth abruptly shifts from under her feet, tumbling her among cracked and steaming rocks. When she raises her head a huge shadow has fallen over the horse. There is a piteous whinny, then a roar. The girl's face is suddenly lit by flames. She scrambles to her feet and rushes back the other way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl hasn't taken a dozen steps when something huge hurtles forward and blocks her way. Something scaly and glittering. She whirls and stumbles off in a new direction. This time she's cut off by a monstrous claw tipped with rapier- like talons. She screams and crawls away. Another claw prevents her escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Membranous wings fold down against the night sky. Up comes the silhouette of a reptilian head swaying on a serpentine neck. There's an angry hiss. A sheet of flame envelops everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian kneels beside a mountain waterfall, having a drink while his men hover in the background. One of them points down the slope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian wipes his mouth unhurriedly and strolls over to look. Far below, half hidden by trees, the little company of Urlanders winds its way through the forest. A frown creeps over Tyrian's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There. I see them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's that old man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where? Which one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That one. That's the man from Cragganmore. Now what's he doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Filling in for the chief, I reckon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weary) What a pity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hodge marches along with the rest. When he's sure no one else is looking he burrows into his garments and brings out the leather pouch containing Ulrich's ashes. Reassured that it's still with him, he tucks it away again. Galen falls into step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pass Valerian, who has dropped out of line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hodge snorts and fusses with his pack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances over and discovers Galen missing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What have you got there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: None of your business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little gold, eh? What do you say I change it into lead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Save your jokes for someone else. Me, I don't care for braggarts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I don't care for frauds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm no fraud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call it fool then. Upstart. Whatever pleases you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hodge, nobody forced you to come along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm here of my own free will, all right. We each do the master's bidding in our own way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if he told you I needed wetnursing, why don't you just turn yourself around and go back home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home, is it? You've seen to that, haven't you? Gone to seed, I'd say...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He walks back along the trail, looking for Valerian. Pretty soon the rest of the travelers are out of sight. He hears the sound of a splash. He turns off the trail and pushes through some shrubbery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Under the oaks and hickory, a forest stream has widened into a quiet pool. A pile of clothes lies on a rock at the edge. Out in the middle, Valerian is treading water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen leans over and splashes some water on his face. Feels good. He shucks his pack and starts to throw off his clothes. Valerian doesn't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Galen is now naked and walking into the water. He swims out toward Valerian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen keeps swimming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Galen has slipped beneath the surface; he doesn't hear.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're too far behind us. Come on out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You go ahead, I'll catch up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a good idea to get separated. Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. I'll be along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right. Don't come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (edgy) You better get back to the group, they're probably worried.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I prefer to swim alone, if you don't mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen works his way through the murky green underwater world. Suddenly, he stops short and stares. He's only a few feet from Valerian's dangling legs. He gasps in surprise. Valerian is no boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen comes shooting to the surface, coughing and sputtering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valerian is pale and frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She propels herself backward, then turns and swims for shore.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: By the gods!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen and Valerian have taken refuge behind separate bushes. Briskly they pull on their clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They finish dressing in silence. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He studies her. She jams a hat down over her head and, once more the young man, stalks off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose you'll tell everyone. Go ahead, I don't care. It's a relief.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to say anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't blame you. I was stupid. Careless. A silly woman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (feeble bluff) Take it easy. I knew the moment I saw you. I've known the whole time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never knew a thing. No one knew. Not since I was born. Go on, run off and tell them. It'll make a great story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry. No one's going to find out. Just tell me: why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ask my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The lottery! Daughters are chosen, but sons are not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. Unless you have plenty of gold or property.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're rich enough, your name never goes in. (bitter) My father is poor. So are a lot of fathers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen walks down to the edge of the pool to retrieve his pack. As he leans over he catches sight of what appears to be a reflection in the water: Tyrian on horseback. He whips around, but no one is behind him. Riveted by the vision, he hurries along the bank to follow it. After a few paces the blurry figure dismounts, unslings a longbow, nocks an arrow and draws the string taut.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (horrified) No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen sprints through the trees. Up ahead is Valerian, walking resolutely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances back at him and grimly keeps on walking. Galen shoots past her and on into the forest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hodge!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen races up the trail rounds a bend and sees the Urlanders coming toward him. Hodge precedes the group with an unsteady gait. He sees Galen, raises up his arms and flops face down on the trail. A long arrow protrudes from his back. Galen kneels beside him. The uneasy company keeps its distance. Hodge struggles to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hodge's hand comes out from under his coat gripping the leather pouch. Galen tugs at it, but Hodge can't let go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen pries the sack out of Hodge's clenched fingers. Suddenly the hand comes up, grabs Galen by the hair, and pulls him near.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dies. Galen frees himself from his grasp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen is frantic. He pulls out the amulet and wraps his hand around it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Hodge has passed on, and Galen's magic has no way to reach him. Suddenly the youth cries out in pain. He drops the amulet and looks at his palm. The device has burned his flesh. Now he becomes aware of troubled Urlanders looking over his shoulder, witness to his failure.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Galen? Can you hear me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hear you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, somebody shot me, but I can still talk. There's something that has to be done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that cockatrice. Ulrich's ashes. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it. Sorry, you'll have to peel it loose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a croak) ...burning water... find the lake, throw it in...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding up the pouch) What are you doing with this, Hodge?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...burning water...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hodge, don't die. Listen to me. You're not going to die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam! (he shakes the body) Excede, mortem! Revoca, vitam!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wind whips the leaden wave tops on a vast rainy lake. The travelers are rowing across in an open longboat, aided by a tattered lateen sail. Valerian mans the steering oar at the stern while Galen broods in the bow. He feels like an imposter in their eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boat pulls into a long narrow waterway with granite cliffs on either side. Moving through swirls of fog, they beach the boat and step out onto a craggy shore. Greil leans over and kisses a rock.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Urland!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The travelers descend a mountain pass and emerge through a wrack of cloud into a gray and cheerless region. Fire- blackened trees dot the barren landscape. As they reach the flatlands, the Urlanders instinctively pick up the pace. Galen slows to inspect the weird surroundings. Valerian trots past him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen falls into step with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen looks around with new interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen stops. High on the slope beside them is a gaping fissure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Galen is already toiling up the incline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The travelers turn to see what's the matter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. Don't dawdle here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The whole kingdom like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. We're near the lair. Keep moving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over there. Doesn't matter. We're in no danger if we just pass through quickly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see it. Let's have a look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Greil! Malkin! Help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen approaches the lair, pausing beside a wooden post with iron manacles dangling from it. He fingers them thoughtfully. Malkin, Greil and Valerian rush up behind him, their faces drawn with worry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Instead, Galen starts into the crack. Greil and Malkin hasten away, but Valerian lingers, watching in mounting frustration as Galen probes further and further into the lair. She picks up a fistful of stones and throws them at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Galen is lost in the gloom. She flees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, you don't have to do this. We know you're a fine young magician. None better. There's no need to prove it to us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are there other entrances?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. One's enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. The road's this way. We'll tell everybody how close you got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coolly) No smoke. How do you know it's in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be a fool. Come away now and live to tell about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead! You're going to die! What a fine trick that will be!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen puts his hand on the rugged wall: the rocks are hot to the touch. Something glinting on the floor catches Galen's eye: an irridescent disk, a dragon scale. It flashes the colors of the rainbow as Galen examines it. All at once the ground shudders; chunks of rock fall from the ceiling. A pall of smoke billows up from the depths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen staggers out of the fissure coughing and gagging in a swirl of smoke. There is no sign of the Urlanders. He throws down his pack, climbs onto a huge boulder and surveys the massive cliffs rising behind the lair. He grasps the amulet and closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now, great mountain, hear my command: Terrae lapsus consignet latibulum draconis! Evanescat latibulum draconis!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: With a thunderous splitting sound, the entire top of the cliff pitches forward and topples onto the lower half of the mountain, sweeping tons of debris into the air. Boulders the size of houses bound down the mountain toward the magician. Eyes wide with awe, he turns and runs for his life. Even as he careens down the slope, chunks of rock rumble past. One catches him at the knee and sends him flying. He covers his head and joins the landslide. Finally the dust lifts and he finds himself in a gully face to face with the cowering Urlanders. They look with real fear at the man who just conjured up the Apocalypse. Tattered and torn, covered with dirt, Galen climbs up out of the shelter for a look at his handiwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The territory has been drastically transformed: the dragon's lair is now buried beneath hundreds of tons of broken granite. The Urlanders look upon the new landscape with stupefaction. Galen grins a triumphant split-lip grin that fails to win them over. Presently they back away and run off down the trail, Valerian in their midst. Galen's grin fades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Village of Swanscombe is little more than a rough and ready collection of thatched huts and mud-daubed outbuildings surrounded by cultivated fields. Dogs sleep in open door- ways; chickens peck around the communal well -- but there are no people in evidence as Valerian and her company troop into town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She trots across the square and enters a deserted blacksmith shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes over to the forge. Hot coals are burning. She becomes aware of a sound -- voices -- chanting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Father? Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She walks across the square toward the voices. She is joined by Greil, Malkin and the other travelers, all of them puzzled by the desolation. As they approach the grange hall the voices grow louder. They seem to be singing. The main doors open briefly and three villagers scamper out, dripping wet and wrapped in white muslin. Valerian and her companions look at each other in astonishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a wooden cistern in the middle of the hall a woman is being held under water. After a few moments she is pulled to the surface by a tall red-haired man with long bony fingers: Brother Jacopus Januensis, a Carthusian monk. There's a wooden cross on his chest and a mad look in his eye. Gathered around him are the missing villagers, every man woman and child, here to be baptised and sing a few newly-learned hymns in praise of Our Lord Jesus Christ.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The travelers enter and mingle with the congregation. Valerian scans the crowd until she locates her father, Simon, a balding sturdy journeyman. He's overjoyed at her return and gives her a hearty embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points to the monk, who is dunking a screaming infant and carrying on about the Bishop of Rome.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now are you cleansed of your sins! Now are you born again, purified in spirit, into the fellowship of Jesus Christ!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome back, my son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father, what are you doing? Have you all lost your minds?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's this monk. He can read and write, and talk too, I'm afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And they listen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shh! They think this a holy place, a tabernacle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is the granary. What kind of welcome is this? I've got news of the sorcerer and news of the dragon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were brave to go, you and your friends. But nobody cares. Listen -- he knows what they want to hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brother Jacopus strides back and forth before the assembly in an inspired state.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Galen, who has just stepped into the hall, tattered, bedraggled and triumphant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He marches to the center of the gathering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures boldly and a fireball crackles at the monk's feet. The holy man scurries back. A hush falls upon the congregation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The man who walks with Christ is not a man to fear a dragon: Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death I will fear no evil! You say you are preyed upon by a foul beast. Yes, but what is the nature of this beast? It comes to you on bat's wings and clawed feet, does it not? It breathes fire, does it not? And it lives under ground. This is no dragon. This is Lucifer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoever it is, he's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nay, brother! It is not as easy as that. Allegiance to Christ, to be sure, but also prayer and confession. These are the arms by which Satan may be put down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're talking about superstition, friend. None of that has anything to do with what I, Galen, have already achieved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Valerian) You brought this stranger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ulrich's apprentice. He's a braggart, but it doesn't matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People of Urland! Send a messenger to the king. Vermithrax is dead. Crushed by the power of the moon and the stars! Laid low by ancient wisdom. Dropped into the Abyss by mystical practice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spoken like a pagan. Every word as reprobate as it is false! (holding up his cross) Solum in hoc signo vinces!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nihil plus mysterium!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A procession of curious villagers winds its way into the badlands. They gather on a promontory overlooking the dragon's lair. They stand there for a long time, a chill wind whipping their garments, trying to understand what's happened. The monk is mightily displeased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed, Galen's act is already the stuff of legend:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the younger villagers scamper forward to the spot where the cave had its opening. With yells and whoops they beat the ground with clubs. In the crowd Simon begins to smile, then to laugh. Soon he leads the villagers in a tumultuous cheer. Brother Jacopus and some of his converts drop to their knees and pray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Praise God! Blessed is he that is humble before the Lord!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your god had nothing to do with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We saw it with our own eyes. He flew to the mountain top. He was a bird. He brought forth lightning. I saw it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The inhabitants of Swanscombe have decked out the town square and are making a night of it. By torchlight they dance merrily to jigs and reels provided by the local fiddlers. Ale flows freely from oak casks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valerian is kneeling before a trunk full of women's clothing. She pulls out a long simple frock, goes to a crude mirror, and holds it up against her body to gauge the effect. Her father comes up behind her. He is angry and frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sits on the bed and puts his head in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at her, trying to imagine what it's going to be like having a daughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Put that away. What if you were seen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to be seen. I want to be seen. Tonight the world finds out that you never had a son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you mustn't do that. It's too soon. We've got to think about this, we've got to make a plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father: the danger is over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. What am I going to say to my friends who still mourn for their lost girls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll say you did what you had to. This is a time for celebration -- and forgiveness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen is surrounded by a crowd of wide-eyed kids and not a few adults, entertaining them by pulling duck's eggs out of their ears and causing coins to disappear. Presently he feels the attention of his audience shift away to someone standing behind him. He turns to find a shy but determined Valerian sweetly decked out in her blue frock. A buzz goes through the crowd. Valerian blushes and wavers: she seems ready to bolt for home. But Galen takes her by the hand, and with conspicuous politesse leads her to the dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's forward, back and around sixth-century style: the young sorcerer can't take his eyes off his partner. But she's too shy to return his gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Valerian doesn't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She still doesn't reply. It's all she can do to keep on dancing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like you've been up to a little sorcery yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or is it witchcraft?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? A real woman never stops talking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it was much easier being a boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & GREIL They stand on the sidelines, watching the young couple step to the music.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The damnedest thing is, she was twice the man of anyone else in the village. Now she's twice the woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grim) Would that I had been as clever as her father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come now, Greil. Don't begrudge a life spared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I begrudge nothing. But I wonder at what we have seen and how it was done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw what I saw. But this jack-anapes was barely ready to carry his master's chamberpot. Isn't it strange that at the very moment the beast is put down we should have a holy man here in the village?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't believe that superstitious Christian rot, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (defensive) It is said God works his wonders in mysterious ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: While the proud Simon dances in the background with his daughter, a group of tipsy villagers clusters around Galen, belching forth a drinking song. The young magician raises his own mug and joins in on the chorus. Abruptly the music stops. The singing dies away. The ensuing silence is broken by the sound of galloping hooves. Presently three horsemen appear at the end of town: Tyrian and his henchmen. They guide their horses forward into the midst of the merry-makers. Tyrian dismounts and looks around in his usual friendly way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The musicians leave their instruments in their laps. Tyrian draws himself a measure of ale and raises it above his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian's smile freezes on his face. He steps in front of Galen, towering over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian regards her coolly, taking in her change of costume and its meaning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Having buried the dragon under a mountain, Galen decides he's not worried about an appearance at court. He smiles at Valerian.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A celebration! Don't stop on my account. You -- musicians, more music!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A toast! To the deed of the day! You see, good news travels fast. The King himself has already heard it. And like yourselves, tonight he's overcome with joy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would you have of us then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a thing. It's this one. (he gestures toward Galen) The King would meet our new benefactor and offer his gratitude to the man who succeeded where so many have failed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobering up) What sort of gratitude? A knife in the belly? An arrow in the back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My young friend, I'd as soon dispatch you as I did the others, and for the same reason. But his Majesty would like a cozy chat, and commands otherwise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't go, Galen. Cast a spell and turn them into toads. It should be easy; that's what they are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, well: still plenty of cheek under those skirts, it seems.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry. I'll be back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Three horses gallop through the moors and fens of central Urland. Galen is tucked up behind Tyrian. On the distant horizon, the battlements of the King's castle glow in the slanting light of a new day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Within the castle is a great hall with shafts of daylight poking in through narrow windows set high in the walls. In the middle of the room stands a carved oak throne. There is Casiodorus Rex, King of Urland, a bearded man in his fifties, as spare and somber as the room in which he sits. He is flanked by a few servants, assorted courtiers and Tyrian. Standing before them all is Galen, looking unhappy. He pours a pitcher full of water into a small glazed goblet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Water continues to pour into the goblet without overflowing. Galen takes a sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King makes no sign. Galen approaches stiffly, takes a scarf and retreats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he's done it: he turns the goblet over and a small chunk of ice hits the floor. The royal reaction is equally frosty. Galen is bombing, and he knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He mutters an incantation. In the audience, Tyrian notes that Galen has his hand wrapped around the amulet. There is a loud clatter as the heavy oak table before the throne begins to jitter and buck. As the wine spills and plates go flying, the King wearily raises a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The table cracks in half and dumps a mess of fruit and crockery at the onlookers' feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This handsome sentiment doesn't go over any better than his tricks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King grimaces as the memories come flooding back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: One of the best things about the water here in Urland is that there's so much of it -- look at that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmm. Good. But not cold enough. Perhaps I could borrow a scarf from his Majesty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cover the goblet, so... remove, so... and behold: winter in a mug!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. How many of you have ever seen a table fly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enough! That's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait, it'll rise now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bother. Not necessary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me: the landslide -- it was accomplished this same way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. And having rendered such unique service to our kingdom, what would you claim as a reward?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please -- no payment. I have always found magical practice to be its own reward. I seek only some yet greater challenge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you ever hear of King Gaiseric? Of course not, you weren't even born. He was my brother, a great King and a valiant man-at-arms. When he ascended to the throne, the dragon was unbridled. No one knew where it might strike next. So he brought forth his broadsword and his spear, assembled a company of his best fighters and went out to do battle. (pause) He was never seen again. But his attack provoked the most terrible reprisals: whole villages incinerated, entire crops burned. Death, famine, horrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) How did you arrogate to yourself the role of savior?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was invited.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not by me. Did you ever consider the consequences of failure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What failure? What's the matter with you people? You want the dragon back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then the beast is dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course. Dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We shall see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two guards thrust Galen into a narrow cell and slam the barred door shut. The young sorcerer waits until they're safely out of sight, then takes out his amulet. He ponders it for a doubtful moment. Suddenly a gloved hand darts in and whips it off his neck and out through the bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He makes an ironic salute and leaves. Galen sits down heavily and stares at the stone walls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Unseen by Galen, a figure clad in silk and lace skitters down a murky dungeon hallway and peers around a corner. Stealing a look at Galen is the Princess Elspeth, a fey beauty in her early twenties. After a moment, spooked by some imagined noise, she flits away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark clouds slide across a pale sun, throwing the ruined land below into shadow. Soon fat droplets of rain are splattering on the rocks above the dragon's lair. With each tiny splash there is a sizzle and a puff of steam. These rocks are hot!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside the barred window, a steady rain is falling. Inside, Galen uses a chunk of limestone to inscribe a pentagram on the floor of his cell. He marks runic signs on the window sill and lintel. Then, positioning himself in the center of the mystic symbol, he raises his hands and spreads his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a long moment when nothing happens. A very long moment. Finally, a thoroughly frustrated Galen leaps to the window and rattles the bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Startled, Galen whirls around to find Elspeth standing outside his cell. She hands some food and blankets through the bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen looks her over. He's never seen anyone so angelic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slips away down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (authoritative) Cubiculum gravis aperat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open up, dammit! Fenestra gravis aperat! Asser gravis aperat! Divinitus!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salve, magistrum iuvenilum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've studied Latin. Greek, too. Me appelo Elspeth, filia regis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't think ill of us. My father is a wonderful man, a wise man. The lottery was his idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't understand. From the moment it began, the dragon was tame. The kingdom prospered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And only a few had to be sacrificed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that's true. Isn't it better that a few should die that many might live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends on who does the dying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, but we all take our chances. My father is a just man. My name is entered on the lists, along with every other young -- GALEN Virgin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maiden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you say so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've participated in every drawing since I came of age.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's true. You don't believe me. You think I'm lying. Well I'm not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. I heard a rumor. Families with money, that sort of thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't listen to rumors. They're lies. I have to go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait -- how long do I have to stay in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Until we know. Not long. Goodbye. Vale. Dormi bene.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: King Casiodorus and Tyrian are huddled over a table piled high with manuscripts and papers. Tyrian clears a spot and sets out a stack of lead bars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King picks up Galen's amulet, and holds it over the bars in his clenched fist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a rustle of skirts and Elspeth appears behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King and Tyrian glance up at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lead remains unchanged, but the King gives out a cry and drops the amulet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian bows and exits. The King uses his sceptre to pick up the amulet and chain. He conceals it in a hollowed-out book and places the volume on a shelf among many others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The King paces over to the window and stares out. The rain has stopped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elspeth sways in dismay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment a tremor passes through the room. King and daughter look at each other in alarm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's enough. Let's not be greedy here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now then: I, Casiodorus Rex do hereby command thou base metal to change thy essence and become gold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not now. Tyrian, remove all but one bar. We'll try it one at a time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father: did you know that some families have paid bribes to stay out of the lottery?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense. By the power of this amulet, justly wielded by my hand in accordance with the laws of Urland, now lead be thou gold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm burned! What devilish thing is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you ever kept my name off the lottery list?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'll be all, Tyrian. You may withdraw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, my dear, what's troubling you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Answer my question: am I not exposed to the same risk as every other man's daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) Your father loves you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a wail) It's true! What have you done to me!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who fills your head with such ideas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The same tremor shakes the bars in Galen's cell. Puzzled, he rolls off his straw palette and gets to his feet. The tremor dies away. Suddenly a violent shaking hits the cell, bouncing Galen off the walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Swanscombe is gripped by the same earthquake. Dodging panicky barnyard animals, Valerian and her father join other frightened villagers in the center of town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Above the dragon's lair, boulders are shifting and grinding together. Massive chunks of stone break loose and tumble down the incline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The shaking has stopped. Rock dust filters down from the ceiling. Galen picks himself up and stares: the door to his cell is off its hinges and is sagging open. He darts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen dashes along the hallway, rounds a corner and stops. At the other end of the passage is Tyrian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He draws his sword and advances. Galen warily retreats. Tyrian breaks into a run. Galen turns and sprints away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You little meddler! It's alive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Unruly horses, terrified by the quake, rush blindly around the courtyard. Hostlers try vainly to catch them. Tyrian leans down from an upstairs window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men below scramble for the gates. Galen bursts out of hiding, sees the untended horses, and swings aboard as one goes past. A cry goes up from the guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen rides like mad for the exit, but he's a half-second late: the doors boom shut in his face. He wheels the horse around. The King's men are coming toward him with pikes. Digging his heels into the horse's sides, he urges the animal back across the courtyard, up the steps and right into the building!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Close the main gate! Quick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There! Stop him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galen gallops into the empty chamber, knocking over the throne and vaulting a table. Hot on his heels are armed soldiers. He kicks the horse again and shoots under an archway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kitchen is already in chaos from the earthquake when Galen charges in on his wild steed. Food, utensils and cooks go flying. He reins in, ducks his head, and squeezes the horse out into a narrow hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He clatters down the passageway. But here comes a contingent of footmen from the opposite direction. Galen rides them into the walls!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The horse scrabbles up the stairs, Galen tucked low against its neck. On the upper landing he comes face to face with Tyrian and more soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen jerks the animal around and plunges back down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get him! Stab the horse!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Whinnying and blowing the horse bursts in, a wild-eyed Galen still in the saddle. He finds himself confronting the King and his daughter. Casiodorus grabs Elspeth and retreats into a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tyrian sweeps in with his men. The doors slam shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galen is trapped. Just as Tyrian reaches for the horse's reins, the animal rears up, rolling its eyes. At that moment the floor heaves and cracks in a new series of shocks. The men at arms go down like ten pins. Tyrian reels back, dodging stone blocks loosened from the ceiling. As the shaking continues, a weakened section of wall gives way. Galen sees daylight! Without even waiting for the quake to cease, he prods the horse across the room and through the wall to freedom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tyrian! Tyrian!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So much for your magic! So much for your sorcery!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The unnerved citizens of Swanscombe gather on the promontory overlooking Galen's landslide. Every few seconds there is a new shudder and more rocks pour down the long slope. Valerian stands trembling with her father. Presently Brother Jacopus elbows his way forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holding a cross before him, he starts up the slope. No one follows. They haven't been Christians all that long. One or two near Valerian get down on their knees and pray silently. Greil looks things over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He strides after the monk. But he's the only one.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me, my brethren. The moment of our fear is the moment of our triumph. This is a sign from God. Follow me, and our faith will send this creature straight to hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You call yourselves Christians?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The determined monk has arrived at the epicenter. His sandals are smoking on the hot gravel. Sweat shines on his face and neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greil toils up the slope a hundred yards back. He's crossing himself, but he's carrying a sickle.
